								So there's a lot of misinformation about this game circulating around about P2W.  It may be because of something from prior to the steam release.  Let me explain why this is nonsense.  You can unlock any part and craft it without spending money.  You can make currency by selling parts you make or selling scrap (used to make parts).  You can buy parts and vehicles but you're going to be stuck with players who match your vehicle's rating.  So it's not like you can buy your way to better equipement than who you're playing against, you can just sort of skip the grind to a small extent.As for gameplay this game is sort of arcadey driving with pretty good physics, reminds me of driving a warthog in Halo, except steering is independent of the camera.  Rounds tend to be fairly short and you can go from one to the other very quickly.  The vehicle customization gives you a lot of freedom and there appears to be a pretty large diversity of weapons 30$ is a bit steep but the game is very very fun.  I'd say it's a must buy for 20$, and I'd still recommend it at 30$, but if that's too much for you check back later.

Early Access Review
Short Version: Enjoyably simple car-fighting arena, plus rotating missions and loot to keep you coming back for more.  Super Special Bonus Feature: Lego Master Builder Mode - Create your own deathmobile with scrap metal and machine guns instead of colorful toy blocks!LAYER 1:  The ArenaCrossout is a game of many layers, but the core of Crossout is a relatively simple arena deathmatch with cars - you choose a vehicle, enter a match full of other players and Bots, and drive around ramming the enemies on the other team and blasting them with various mounted weapons until they blow up.  The graphics are nice, the controls and gameplay are rather basic (so it's easy for newbies to jump into the game), and the matches are quick and explosive enough to be entertaining.The arena mode is probably where casual players will spend most of their time. Driving around and blowing up friends and strangers for a few quick rounds is plenty of fun, and the battles are weighted by class so that you'll be matched with vehicles of roughly similar power.  There's also a nifty system of durability for every component of a car, so you can take an enemy apart piece by piece.  You could destroy an enemy's tires to ruin their mobility, then take out their unprotected deathcannon on the roof, leaving your opponent as a useless lump of metal taking feeble machine gun potshots at anyone driving by - at least until someone puts them out of their misery.However, arena battles in any game can grow stale, and Crossout's simplistic arena battles probably would not keep players around for long on their own.  Fortunately, the Crossout developers planned ahead for this and included...LAYER 2: Mission ModeIn addition to simple arena fights, Crossout includes a variety of 'raid' missions where you team up with a few fellow road-warriors to complete various objectives, such as protecting a transport vehicle or taking down certain enemy structures before the enemy can lay the smack down.  These rotating missions provide some welcome variety and challenge to the game, and are a fun option for casuals and regulars alike.  LAYER 3:  Builder Mode With just the arena and mission modes, Crossout is already a pretty entertaining game - and it is likely that these battle-modes are where casuals and semi-casuals will spend the vast majority of their time.  However, builder mode is what really sets Crossout apart.  Instead of simply choosing between a variety of preselected cars for your matches, Crossout allows you to build your own awesome amalgam of arms and armor.The builder mode is rather tricky, and I have not quite gotten the hang of designing cars from scratch yet.  Fortunately, for inept builders like me, players are able to use 'blueprints' to quickly copy a design.  These include basic cars created by the developers, as well as cars made by people gracious enough to share the results of their own experience and creativity.  These blueprints give more casual players (or those who simply want to blow stuff up instead of building it) a way to upgrade their car without worrying about the nitty-gritty building details.  Meanwhile, experienced players can fully utilize the building system to create personalized metal monstrosities kitted out in a myriad of ways, from heavily-armored rocket tanks to super-speedy, shotgun toting dune buggies.LAYER 4:  The LOOTAh yes, finally, the glue that holds almost every modern game together - the loot!  As you graduate from Crossout's basic arena mode to raid missions and more, you're eventually going to see someone driving something bigger and badder than you and want to upgrade your own ride to match.  Of course, in order to do - you'll need to get some new vehicle parts.This is where Crossout's looting system comes into play.  The looting system balances a generous amount of core drops with rare, high-tier gear that will take quite a while to work up to.  In addition to finding random pieces of gear with every match, the daily missions and 'seasonal' campaigns allow you to save up various in-game currencies to pick up some of those rare, higher grade weapons.  This provides a nice incentive to keep popping back in to play a few rounds every day or two.  The loot in Crossout is nice and plentiful, and you'll quickly gain access to better engines and more powerful weapons simply from playing the game.  Unfortunately, it should be noted that the freedom to design almost any car/truck/tank you can imagine comes with its own nasty limitation:  if you wanna build it, you gotta have the parts, and boy-howdy are there a heck of a lot of parts.  Chasing down every single piece for a nifty blueprint can be quite a challenge, and the sheer amount of options when designing your own car can be rather overwhelming.  The daunting loot system and the amount of grind necessary to get a large stock of higher end components will keep dedicated players from immediately farming everything and getting bored too soon - but this also makes the game feel like an enormous grindfest, and is why some players have complained about Crossout being 'pay to win'.  As an alternative to farming components yourself, Crossout's purchasable vehicle packs offer a quick way to get all the parts for a well-built automobile, along with a large chunk of currency to purchase additional upgrades.  Personally, I think that the Pay-to-Win complaints have a bit of merit, but are largely unfounded.  It is certainly true that buying a pack will give you a leg-up when starting off, but the cars themselves are not the highest-tier options; You could always farm gear to make something better.  The DLC vehicle packs are mainly a time-saver to give players a quick boost, or to provide spiffy new vehicles for those who don't want to delve too deeply into the 'Building' part of the game.Conclusion:Crossout combines simple, enjoyable arena gameplay (drive, shoot, car explodes) with a relatively deep building and looting system that allows you to personalize your car in looks, handling, and deadly loadout.  This enables the game to appeal to casuals, grinders, and master-builders alike, as there is literally something for everyone.  Crossout is definitely a game worth trying, even if it's simply to reminisce about Twisted Metal or pretend to be Mad Max for a few rounds.  Who knows, you might just like it enough to get sucked into the daily raid missions as you farm up enough loot to design your own Super-Death-Car.EARLY ACCESS WARNING:  Please be *fully aware* that this game will be F2P on release.  The paid Early Access version of this game is for a vehicle bundle as well as early beta access.  I highly recommend this game on the try-before-you-buy F2P model, but I can only recommend the $30 Early Access to those who are completely in love with the idea of building their own vehicle of doom.Received a free copy for testing/reviewing purposes. 								I have played this game from very early on in the CBT (Closed Beta Testing) and I'm quite excited to see it's release on Steam! If you have played one of the "Twisted Metal" games on your Playstation consoles,you'll find elements of that game in this one. The core of the game is to go into battles,collect parts and pieces which you use to craft better parts in order to make your vehicle more effective in combat. The battles and building are fairly straight forward and are easy to get into. However,the crafting is a lot more in-depth and does require a bit of time to master. So if you play it clever and take out the guns of the enemy vehicle first,they will be defensless until the moment they go BOOM!Besides the standard PvP content,there is also Co-Op game modes,where players fight together waves of enemies or defend specific locations (like Oil rigs for example). Once you have the basics down,you will just spend hours upon hours by just building your dream destruction machine,as I have found myself doing countless of times.I highly recommend this game to any player who likes to build his own creation and likes quick explosive action. It's also a game suited for players who have little time on their hands to play. The PvP matches only last up to 3 minutes ,so you can rack up a couple battles within a short period of time to give you that injection of fun you needed.

Early Access Review
 Crossout DISCLAIMER: I received this product for no cost for the purpose of reviewing. However, this does not affect my views and opinions of the game.Crossout is a third-person vehicle shooter where you craft your own machines and take on other players (and bots) in challenges. It reminds me of another game called "Gas Guzzlers Extreme" in which you race your vehicles while trying to destroy your opponents. Both of these games take place in a post-apocalyptic Mad Max-esque setting. The thing that sets this game apart from others is it's crafting and building system, where you craft new parts and weapons for your machine to do battle. -------- Graphics: 7 / 10  The graphics are really well done. The vehicles, maps and even the garage give off this grunge-y feel which of course contributes the post-apocalyptic setting of the game. The quality of the art assets and objects are great and is what you would expect from a modern game. Although not seen very often, the game has some cool character designs as well. The vehicles can be custom made to the player's liking and play-style, so whatever you want your machine to look like, given the parts you have, is up to you. The game surprisingly wasn't that demanding on my PC though anything lower than a mid-tier graphics card and CPU would not be recommended for this title.-------- Sound: 7 / 10  The sound assets of the game are pretty good. The gun shots and general car noises are decent and they do get the job done. The in-game music/soundtrack is surprisingly nice and fits in well with the motif of the game. -------- Mechanics: 7 / 10  The mechanics are competent and I haven't encountered any bugs or annoyances within them. You'll spend a lot of time in your garage putting together and testing your automobile. You can craft different parts for your vehicle using scrap you acquire while playing. You can also unlock new recipes for parts and this depends on which faction you are currently in. You can unlock new factions as you continue to play and gather recipes for each. You can customize your automobile and put parts wherever you want too (as long as they connect to your vehicle). You do different challenges and quick-matches for a chance to get get loot at the end of each round. The combat gameplay is solid, and although there are a few different game modes which I haven't explored yet, I've mainly played assault/capture the point. There are daily "raids" you can do, though I have not been able to do any because of the lack of players currently. There is a market place where you can sell and buy new parts. The game has a currency, and you can obtain this currency by selling parts on the market. You can also use real money to buy the in-game currency to buy parts. This is something that may turn off a lot of people from the game as it is possible to spend a bunch of real money in order to get the best parts for your car. However, all vehicles have a gear score, and if/when enough people are playing, I'd imagine the game would match players with similar gear scores together. This would mean that players with machines similar in strength would be matched against each other, rather than getting destroyed by vehicles with a higher gear score. -------- Final Personal Remarks: It's not a bad game, and I do see myself playing it from time to time. Much like how I did with "War Thunder" another title published by Gaijin. I'm not a big fan of the "pay for currency" method, but I don't think it'll affect me too much, especially with a gear scaling system put into place. The big problem with the game right now is that there's no one playing because it's in early access with a hefty price tag. It kind of wards people away. The game will eventually be free to play which will allow more people to try the game, though right now I can't even get try the game's "raid" system because I can never match up with enough people. The quick matches are usually populated with bots as again, it's hard to find other people to play with. I do see a lot of people enjoying this game and I do plan on playing it more to see where it goes. I'm not certain how difficult it will be acquire specific parts yet but right now it's not too bad. Thanks to the Devs for giving me the opportunity to review the game, as well as anyone who took this review into consideration, I hope it helped.

								When I saw this game on the store, it reminded me of the "Death Race" trilogy. Driving around in a car with guns you've designed and build yourself.Here is a summary of my review, you can fully read it if you want to:Pros: - It's fun;- You can build your vehicle as you want;- Easy to use interface;- Doesn't get boring too fast;- You can rebuild your whole vehicle as many times as you want, without penalties;- The AI is programmed nicely (not too bad, not too good);Cons:- Every game you play is 1v1, 1v2 (or the other way around) or 2v2 with AI;- Not too many players play this game;- AI has some silly movements at the start of a game;Full review:When I started up the game, it was originally in Russian, but that's probably due to the developers, and then the tutorial started. Every level (so far) you reach gives you items and a little story, and with those items you can design and build your vehicle as you desire.As for the building itself, it's quite easy. The game has a slick interface so building your own vehicle isn't too hard. I'm not one for designing my own vehicles, but I found that if you take one of the designs the game gives you and remove everything (I placed it onto the ground so I could grab it again) and keep the frame, making your own vehicle is rather fun.The game offers a vast number of items and weapons you use to build your vehicle, and because it is set in a post-apocalyptic world, most items are scrapped from other vehicles, such as an airplane cockpit for your cabin, or van walls, doors and windows. Building your vehicle in such a manner that your cabin is protected but at the same time you have enough space to mount a few guns and blow your opponents away, is critical and again, fun to do. The game also gives you certain sprays you can use on most of the items, to give your vehicle the colour you want.The game's population, however, is very low. The game offers two types of battles you can do: for items, or raids. Raids consist of (usually) 3 to 4 players against a group of AI. Battles for items consist of players vs players, and the empty slots are filled with AI. So far I have joined fights where it was 2 players vs 2 players, and the rest was AI. Then again, every battle I participate in, has 1 or 2 players in it.The battles themselves are quite fun and can be quite challenging sometimes. Two types of battles (for items) are available: one where your target is capturing the enemy base, or to capture the neutral base. You can win by either fully capturing the base or destroying every enemy. If all players are killed, who-ever captured most of the base wins, or who-ever has more vehicles available in case no-one captured a base.The last game I played was another player and myself versus two other players. I managed to destroy the guns of both the enemy players and was shooting at one of them to destroy their cabin and thus their vehicle, but the game ended. Even though my teammate and I were still driving around shooting them, and they were driving around without guns being unable to do anything, it was a draw. Trust me, if we had 10 more seconds, they would both be destroyed.As for the AI, it's not the best, but at the same time it's pretty well made. When a game starts, one or two AI tend to crash. Whether it's into your vehicle, into another AI vehicle or into the wall, every start gaurantees a crash or two. However, half a minute into the game, the AI does a very good job. They're not too accurate, but not too stupid either. Unlike players, they just aim for your vehicle or cabin.

								I'm writing this review to explain how it isn't pay-to-win in any way, shape, or form. For a quick "Do I recommend this game?" Yes I do. Hands down. Even in its early access-closed beta state, it is extremely addictive and fun. It needs polishing but thats why it is in closed beta, for feedback and improvement. 8/10 (for a free game when it launches, I think it deserves 8-9/10). NOW onto p2w. In the game you can purchase "packs". These packs simply give you a better boost to starting the game by giving you a stronger starter vehicle, the performance of these cars is nowhere near any higher tier cars ive faced. Other than that slight boost, you cannot buy ANYTHING else. You cannot buy parts with money, cars, or !Coins!. Coins get you anything you want (depending on the cost), if you could buy coins, it would be pay 2 win. But since you can't it isn't even close to pay2win. Besides, having a strong car won't even guarentee you a win. You cannot carry in this, no matter how hard you try. Sure, some games you will wipe the whole team, but that is every so often. Otherwise this game does require skill and there are counters in the game for each style of battle. Melee, long range, and sustain as I would lable them. Also due to the limitations in crafting (energy, part limit, and weight: all which can be increased with level and parts to a certain extent) no one can be overly OP. (unless you are using a Leviathan which is No Holds Barred in custimization).Side Note: The custimization is great. It is truly what I wished the Twisted Metal franchise should have been. EDIT: I would also like to add that, yes, during American day-time hours, the game can have low player count and long que times. That is because it isn't very popular here yet, it is a Russian made game so it is more popular in Europe. If you switch servers Europe, that will help you slightly, but playing later at night will help more since that is when Europeans are online mainly. Otherwise, wait until more people get the game, it only just came out on Steam and IS in closed beta, so low player count is to be EXPECTED. When the game is Free, you can surely expect a HUGE rise in the player base.EDIT2: With the help of the power level system. Even if you bought as much as possible from the packs, you would simply be put with other people who bought the same stuff. So it isnt pay 2 win if you are just against people just as strong as you, making it an even match.

I see 2 shotguns, so its a close up fighter, but doesnt have much armor, so its really great for driveby shooting if you know how to aim while driving by/circling around. You dont want to be standing still with this car unless you want your opponent to shoot off your shotguns/wheels until you die. Is the car itself worth $30? 								Ok first thing is first its a shooter yes, is it counter strike, no. That out of the way if you ever played robocraft, its like mad max meats robo craft. That is what drew me to this I saw the P2W comments then realised this is gonna be f2p so these just the usual needs an excuse crowd. This game just like other new games Gaijen is helping out like Starconflict has both PVP and PVE going on you do not have to be a master at PVP, like some people think. So to some up, like Robocraft meets mad max, gonna be f2p before year is out, but has PVP and PVE optionsAlright lets start with like Robocraft, meets mad max. If you can't tell form videos and what not you can make your own rides thes all kind of look like standard real life cars but in reality its like robocraft they were just built that way, because it works. You get specaly under carrage parts you can make them long and wide if you fee like it. But most don't got wide as you attack head on normally or camp head on its not bad idea to go skinny and long to fit all your parts.Like Robocraft its based score system but unlike it where you limited on what parts to use, any part you can get your hands on and you do earn armor parts via grind, but can buy, earn or craft ingame all the non armor parts its just a bit of work for the high end stuff. Now the way this works isn't MMO style its a shooter for one, like robo craft its score based every bock you can use has its own score, and stats so you can't make a an armed beast with legendary guns and be in the low level matches you basicly have to be a a pair of tracks, a cabin and a gun to do that lol. Anyways that is how it works.Now some people new to this think every one who is higher then them must be magicly using hte best ever parts in spades. But you can't do this, you can't rock high end parts with out compromising and using paper armor on most your rig. Now what you do is armor one key spot normally the front people don't get that and shoot that one armored part and think its all a tank but a shotgun or cannon shell to the side and you rip off half their stuff there, thanks to the score system, or just shoot off the gun(s) if you got an accurate weapon like maching gun or aiming with a cannon.Now I got that covered here is the next part people don't get, this is going f2p all these max levels you may see, I hardly see, a rank 40. These guys are gonna be reset to one just like you when CBT ends, then on top of that tons of new players with out good gear are gonna pile in right 98% of players paid some kind of cash and bought some pack full of nice parts to start with on day one, but there is a whole world of cheap gamers who will show up when this is new with none of that, and of course complain your too op with your 2 shotguns in the steam pack lol.I warn people of this becuase that freaks them out, yes your are gonna get wiped, but your playing now to learn how to play so one day one, you can b-line for your fave playstyles parts, you can use this time to dink around get killed, kill a few yourself, and look at all these vets builds when you die. Don't run to the garage and rage that you can't reque till your rig is out. You are gonna get wiped anyways, so look at the others when your dead. Make a note of how they did their rigs, how they play the game, and learn so you can try it out. Who cares if you go bust doing it, on day one you are reset as well as the rest of us. I learned heaps from that and now lets play videos of other people with no clue like me, testing and failing or suceeding.Last bit this has a bit of PVE and PVP the way it works is simple you can't just PVE all day long unless you want work for it. PVE requires gas in your tank, every day I think you get more, but if you pvp with a feul barrel, it cost no energy used for impartant parts like guns and weapong radiators, but catch is you want to hide it and protect it, because its a gas tank it explodes when broken and can tear up parts near it when it goes. But you put that in your build and now every win you bring back some gas, and to make it more awsome it doesn't go in the tank with 200 limit you pile it in your storage with the parts for making your rig. So you can pile up tons of it, and sell it if need be to other players for stupid cheap, not really worth it, or just right click pour in the tank to top it off so I can PVE all day.And what is the big diff minus the gas PVE gets you coupons, collect 300 and you can make a loot crate. Think of it like those chests you need p2w keys in other games to open but you don't in this. You open it up and its a chance you gonna get a part from any faction in game of blue or purple qulity or small chance you get a cometice. Now the cosmetic you think oh that is lame these give you rep bonus if you use them on your rig, basicly exp bonus and you can sell them to other players on the market who want that bonus, or just want to make a pretty car with it. You get a cap for these coupons every day based on diffculty, You also copper sheets used to make blue quality gear, and some wires for high end stuff. So even PVPers need to do a little basic PVE if they wnat stay ahead.And that long winded reveiw is basicly what you need to know I didn't share any fun stories or cool stuff like that just basic stuff you should want to know before buying the steam pack. Things people come in and have no idea about. So to sum up again its like robocraft meets madmax, its score based not level. Its gonna be f2p, you could wait till then but then you could also rage about not knowing anything about how the game works first hand, and about people like me using are 2 little shotguns to tear up your stuff, even though I have expeinced guys with common grade lmgs tear them off all the time in pvp leaving me only with the abilty to try and ram before my wheels are shot off next lol And lastly it has pretty decent pvp, and pve system you need a bit of both but could just go all in either one, if you want work a little more, and buy and sell things to get the copper from not raiding, or buy gas because you don't like pvp.

So far the matchmaking has been pretty solid too.The PvE "Raids" matches can last a little longer than the PvP matches (Depends on the type of "Raid", Some last longer than others.) but still don't drag on. There is a good variety of these Raids with more (Harder) ones unlocked as you level up.The vehicles control fairly well and it has a good amount of customisation regarding binding different weapons to different keys/Mouse button.The Building:Possibly one of the best things about this game, The actual building "Editor" has been done really well, Really solid and I haven't really had any issues with it so far, Only thing I'd say is the camera controls can be a little confusing to begin with but I got used to it fairly quickly.You get a decent amount and variety of parts to begin with and once you gain a few levels you'll have more than enough parts to play around with.Being able to instantly test drive your vehicle is really useful as well, Really nice addition.One of the most fun things in this game is just building the vehicles and seeing what works and what doesn't. You'll also never really meet the same player created vehicle twice as there are so many options.Performance/Graphics:Performance wise it runs really well, I can run it maxed out on a Intel G3258 and GTX 950 at a solid 60FPS, Really well optimised game.Graphics wise it looks really good considering how well it runs, Haven't noticed any major graphical issues at all.Regarding this bundle, the vehicle "Blueprint" you get is pretty good, Does well and is a good starting point for you own creations, 2000 in-game coins is also a good amount for the price considering you get access to the closed Beta as well.Overall a very fun game with a lot of potential, Would definitely recommend.PS: A Linux version would be nice Devs. ;)

								With No Man's Sky being a complete fail. Very hard to decide what games you should be buying these days. Some key features that stick out in Crossout are that they monitor chat fairly strict. You will fight along side and vs devs a lot, and they are always in chat talking and telling more about updates and fixes. RoboCraft is on the side lines while Crossout is the MVP of the game. Gaijin still updates many of the games they have released. They did ruin World of Tanks with some bad updates and very high pay to win items. Yet they still have held a high player base across many games. They do like micro transactions a lot. This game can be a bit of a grind to start but what game isn't? Also if you don't spend a dime on the game, you will still be able to kill the players who did. The game is based on a PowerScore which each building item or gun has, applying more items to the build you have will raise the power score. Then the PowerScore of what you have built will separate you into brackets for the match. People will have a epic item in low brackets, but it's not to say you won't even have a chance. Knowing the maps, working with teammates(Can't stress that enough) also having just a all around steady build that works for you will and can do so much on putting up a good fight during a match. I highly recommend Crossout, even with the price tag set for now. For me its the mass assortment of items and ways you can really build that keeps me going. It's hard to explain really.. but just the factor of having a better build not even to say better guns, you can use all grey guns and still win when in a match with people using epic guns. All depends on how well you build, and with a mass amount of items to build with you can tweak a playstyle down to a tee.

								I've been waiting for this game to come to Steam for some time now, it's finally here! Hurrah!A couple excerpts from the store page: "In 2021 a mysterious viral epidemic known as the ‘Crossout’ swept the planet, countries and populations simultaneously began to fall at an alarming rate all over the Earth." ... "Twenty years have passed after ‘Crossout’. Humans still remember their life before the disaster. As always, there are groups trying to recover the old world, while others enjoy the chaos and destruction. But there are those who are not human any more. They hide their faces behind masks, and their motives are unknown"Your goal in Crossout is to survive this plagued planet by crafting parts from pieces which you have aquired either through battles or from the black market and then build and outfit your own unique vehicle.  The crafting system might look rather daunting to any newcomer but is actually rather simple and straightforward. You must aquire the specified parts from either combat or the blackmarket and continue to craft the item. Depending on the item it can take from 5 seconds to 120 hours for the item to craft, and yes, that is real life time. But don't fear, you can speed up this crafting process by using in-game currency which can be got by just selling parts you've gathered over time. The black market is run by the players. Have an item you wish to sell? Well chances are someone has set up a buy order and if you need the cash quick you can simply sell it there instantly, but usually the prices are really low so you can put the item up for sale with a price of your choice and wait for someone to buy it. Simple!The combat is usually very fast paced but can be throttled down a bit depending on your build. For example the players have created a sort of sniper class using either rockets/missiles or large caliber cannons at long range, there is a scope modification which can be aquired which really helps with this. There is also an exhibition tab in-game where players can share their vehicle builds with others. You can download those builds and use them. Now many people have been calling this game Pay to Win but in reality it is not, it is Pay to Progress. The packs simply move you ahead quicker but everything which can be got from the packs can be got from just playing the game, that is, asside from the avatars.All in all this game looks very promising and so far has been a blast to play. Here is my very first build made from scratch: http://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/447367542025090944/8A1364DD9E773F7B03B8E1EDFBA2EB8E1078D28E/tl;dr A crazy fun game and you should definitely give it a try. What is Crossout?   Crossout is an arcade styled build and fight game where you construct vehicles out of scrap parts and battle with other players or AI enemies. Battling rewards you with materials and parts which can be used to create other parts or sell them on a market. The market is very economy based with buying and selling prices. Usually selling parts yields tax which prevents players from exploiting the market. As you level up and build stronger vehicles, you gain affinity with four factions (Engineers, Lunatics, Nomads, and Scavengers). Leveling with these factions allows you to craft stronger parts at crafting benches (which you have to rent out).The good.   As of December 2016, the game costs around $30.00 for closed beta access. As the decription suggests; the game may go free2play next year so I dont recommend buying it at the moment, but it sure will be good when it is free. The graphics card usage and cpu usage is quite low for stronger cpus and gpus. This suggests that you dont need a high-end rig to play it, but you shouldn't play it on a potato. The graphics are decent considering the strength of the gpu needed. Battles themselves can get intense as different player designs yields different play styles. One player may have a melee based vehicle when another player may have a sniper based vehicle. There are a great assortment of weapons. from heavy cannons to explosive javelins, this game has so many weapon variants.The bad.   Sometimes the game may break and you loose progress or your account and you need help from the developers. Just so you know, the support is very bad. The devs refuse to help you and blame it all on you. If you continue to plea, they will keep denying it and give you false facts. The game itself can get a little repetitive. Build, fight, repeat. It's one of those games you play one hour, then break two hours.The verdict.Pros:-Almost priceless.-Well optimised.-Many play styles.Cons:-Bad customer support.-Repetitive8.5/10

								Edit: The developer has been in contact with as I requested, I am eager to see how the final release turns out!Edit 2:After talking with the developer and learning a few tricks and an update I am happy to report that I have changed my review to a recommend.The positives about this game:The fighting is awesome, I found out that you can make in game teams so if you get three people that agree to fight with you, you never have to wait to do a PvE battle!The physics and damage are pretty fair, I haven't found to many weapons OP.There are now daily challenges you can do and daily and weekly crates you can get that fill some of the void of how to get items and scrap to make items.This game is all about building the best tank you can and destroying your enemies with it!The neutral about this game:This game is also all about grind, with level locks every step of the way and the sheer cost of everything to be crafted or bought in the market grinding is what you will be doing the whole game.However, if you were to ask me how to make grinding fun I would tell you shooting an enemies tires off then using a grain thresher on their car till it blows up, or cloaking a 105mm cannon to sneak up behind someone and show them how foolish it was to put all their armor in the front.This game has done something I found very hard in the past, it makes grind fun. So even though I find fault in level locking things and various other leveling related problems, I do not give it a negative score for that, because when you are in the swing of things you will look up and realize you advance three levels without noticing!The negative about this game:The marketplace is a little broken including everything being way over price and the fact it has a strange 10% tax for no reason.The Item Crafting is very broken! Remember what I said about grind: This is what is needed for crafting a 1st level ammo pack:2 - Basic 75mm cannons = 300 scrap each to make / 15 from a standard battle = 120 minutes of battling2 - Basic Machine guns = 300 scrap each  to make / 15 from a standard battle = 120 minutes of battling2 - Basic Shotguns = 300 scrap each  to make / 15 from a standard battle = 120 minutes of battling50 copper = approx 7 a game x 3 average minute game time = 21 minutes of just fighting450 Scrap (none from the 6 guns we broke down to make this?) = 90minutesso 7 hours and 51 minutes of game play to make a single 1st level ammo pack, but wait it takes a real time hour to craft (again for some reason unknown to me)So the actual time is 7Hrs and 51 minutesNow, you can buy stuff from the market, there are daily challenges and seasonal ones to help with the cost, but I would like to ask did 8hrs sound like a good idea in development?Did someone grind to make an ammo pack to see what it felt like?If at anytime you decide not to make that item, you will not get 1/10th of the price back it cost you to make or buy those guns if you sell them.If you want to hook people for the long haul, add new things into the game, the whole game is about battling and it's fun as heck! Don't go for the cheap hooks like this, ditch the weapon requirement or at least make them make sense and you'd have a great crafting system.All in all the crafting is the only thing I really have a problem with now, and I plan on buying what I need from the in game market so if you are a person who does the same I highly recommend this game!If you like making someone wish they had prepared for your triple rocket launcher cloaking sneak attack that removed all their guns and half their armor, then this is also the game for you!Happy hunting!

								Early Access Watcher Reviews CrossoutUpdate Version: 0.3.2Disclosure: This game copy was bought by the reviewer.Gameplay Footage: 


YouTube™ Video: Crossout with The Mute Cynic - Early Access Watcher - 

			Views: 58		

			In 2021, Crossout eradicated a good chunk of the global population. Twenty years later, some look to restore the old ways, others flourish in the madness of the modern age.		

I have had very little experience with the publisher of this game outside a few hours spent playing War Thunder to varying degrees of success. The developer, on the other hand, is new on my radar. Each company has dealt with vehicular gameplay in some degree and it does transfer over (at least in regards to War Thunder) over to Crossout. It has been out for quite awhile and finally ventured into the Early Access program in the form of a paid entry closed beta, which is not uncommon when you look at previous adapters of the practice (Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex, SNOW). I have spent roughly 10 hours exploring the options on offer at the game's current stage and have determined that the game is surprisingly fun, but not worth the price of admission. Driving mechanics are manageable, but feel extremely wonky. I have tested many different vehicle types and they all seem to slide regardless of the bulk of the weight. This is thankfully balanced by the great physics concept used for crashes, impact and movement when over certain terrain. You can lose wheels, weapons and most of your car's frame during combat when you receive damage, which affects your speed, movement and can render you defenseless. Certain car parts can help negate some of these issues (auto-flipper instead of waiting 30 seconds) or more protective parts can be used around weapons to keep them from popping off. Weapon fire requires a line of sight depending on the weapon type such as shotguns not being able to fire if you are pointing them towards you. I find the driving annoying, but I am shocked to admit how fun this can make the overall game be.Gameplay is comprised entirely of the vehicular combat with Battles making up the PvP segment of the game. It is fast-paced deathmatch mayhem delivered in short three minute matches with a single life to fight on. Two teams will collide to either eliminate every player on the opposing team or capture the enemy/neutral base. Battles will be the best option for the time being due to the extremely long queue times for the Raid events. Battles can be populated by bots if players are not available and provides near instant queue times. The AI for the bots is a mixed bag especially when the layouts of each vehicle and the unevenness of the weapon's power can make some bots weak as wicker baskets stuck on their sides or absolute powerhouses able to carry matches. Other times it is hard to tell if the AI is just terrible at driving or a fault of the floaty driving mechanics. I would consider this a primary issue, but actually having the bots eliminates the problems with a low player population for certain game modes.When you can find enough people to do Raids, you are given a randomly selected branch of objectives ranging from gathering supplies, defending positions and defending convoys from raiders. They are purely PvE missions and require gas to participate, which is refueled daily. Daily missions provide additional scrap and Season objectives reward scrap and other items. Everything you get inevitably contributes to the ultimate objective: making an effective vehicle.Once you win a couple of matches the customization opens up to allow modifications to your starter vehicle or just build something original. You are reasonably limited to how many parts you can equip at the start and the right to add more pieces the higher you level up. The garage allows six degrees of freedom to get in close, allowing a more precise angle to slip parts behind finicky corners. Every key command is listed on the top of the UI and makes referencing painless. It is just a shame I have yet to find a way to change the keybinding for these options. Accidental deletion of a part becomes a frequent annoyance due to this dilemma, which makes the use of the undo key-combination crucial. It is semi-user friendly with the possibility for some outrageous designs as long as you have the part allowance to handle it. You can even test out your vehicle before risking defeat in combat. The underlying issue will be obtaining parts and the unpleasant means to get them. Parts and equipment can be crafted, won through matches or rewarded through crafted cargo containers (RNG Loot boxes) using rented out workbenches of your respected organization. You can also buy these parts using the in-game coin currency obtainable by selling items on the auction house or buying it outright. Special parts are also needed in the form of copper (Raids), wires and electronics (Battles) to upgrade select parts to higher tiers. This process can take a great deal of time and effort due to the wait required once an item is selected for crafting. It adds up the higher tier you decide to craft with the alternative of buying said items eliminating the endless farming. Enter the debate over pay-to-win or in this case, pay-to-quicken. The amount of time needed to create just one high tier weapon can be eliminated by either buying one of the packages with pre made vehicles or using coins to buy them. Coins can take forever to get if you only manage to sell what you get from Battles so the coins grabbed from the packages can eliminate that as well. Vehicle power does determine the type of players you can get matched with, but people can get into higher tiers by buying their way into it instead of farming endlessly to get the materials to make a powerful car. Time equals power in this scenario and skill can only carry you so far in a fight with a tank. My only gripe is the use of micro-transactions and paid packages in a paid game, but with it going free-to-play in the near future the issue I have will not exist. There are other issues I noticed in the form of connection issues and texture quality on certain maps, but I will generally found very little to consider game-hindering. The music is rather nice with some varied genres represented in the hub while the visual aesthetic remains pleasing to the eye (if not a bit dated). The number of maps and objectives available are decent. It is a enjoyable driving game with fast combat, albeit slow due to the downtime from the single life system. That being said, all of this does not justify the $30 price tag ($20 if you go through their website) and I cannot recommend it at such a price. It is best to wait until it finally hits free-to-play before trying this out; it will be more complete then. Pros- Fun, easy combat - Building possibilities for vehicles is vast- Visually decentCons- Micro-transactions pay-to-quicken- Bot AI + vehicle layouts = hit or miss- Queues can be atrocious for Raids

Honestly, I'm conteplating paying for something myself; but maybe that was the devs intentions all along:  Put me in an unfair competition to encourage me to go the pay-to-win route.TL:DRThe game's rating structure is not balanced; but I REALLY REALLY REALLY want to like this game.  = (
